moves.4... dxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 h5: The Alapin gambit.  Id never seen this line before but it looks interesting.  Black does not bother saving his bishop. White has to decide when and if to take the sacrifice.
moves.7. d3 Qf6 8. Nbd2 Ne7 9. Re1 Ng6 10. Re3: Blacks almost in trouble but white has no killer blow. The black rook has to stay on the d file to prevent the knight check at d5.
moves.38. Rc4 Rd2 39. Rc6 Rd6 40. Rxd6 Bxd6 41: Bishop takes knight leads to a lost k and p ending so black will keep his bishop and white retains his knight.
moves.44... Kc5 45. b6: A tactic.  if the king swallows the pawn indigestion follows Nd4 check and the bishop is lost.
The next few moves demonstrate the superiority of the bishop over the knight in the endgame but is not enough  to win the game for black.
I was dreaming of victory.  At this point  I realised the truth.  This is the wrong bishop.  I need a light squared bishop.  Whites king can never be forced out of the corner.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C69), exchange variation, Alapin gambit
